title: Amazon deal will disrupt plans for affordable housing on Long Island City sites
description: Amazon's plans to expand into Long Island City may cost Mayor Bill de Blasio - and New York City - approximately 1,500 units of affordable housing. Two sites that will house the future offices of the e-commerce giant were originally intended for residential d…
content: A spokesman for Amazon confirmed there will be no housing in its Long Island City complex. | AP Photo Amazons plans to expand into Long Island City may cost Mayor Bill de Blasio and New York City approximately 1,500 units of affordable housing. Two sites that… [+2890 chars]
fulltext:
A spokesman for Amazon confirmed there will be no housing in its Long Island City complex. | AP Photo Amazon deal will disrupt plans for affordable housing on Long Island City sites

Amazon’s plans to expand into Long Island City may cost Mayor Bill de Blasio — and New York City — approximately 1,500 units of affordable housing.

Two sites that will house the future offices of the e-commerce giant were originally intended for residential development, before Amazon chose them in a nationwide contest for its new headquarters.

Story Continued Below

Most — if not all — of that intended housing is now off the table.

“The fact that massive public subsidies are helping eliminate affordable housing units is just the latest reason this bad deal needs to be torn up and thrown away,” said state Sen. Michael Gianaris, who represents Long Island City.

Plaxall, which owns land around the Anable Basin, was prepared to ask New York City for permission to build up to 4,995 new homes on a 14.7-acre site on the East River, 1,250 of which developers would have set aside for low- and middle-income New Yorkers. Most of that site will now be subsumed into Amazon’s office campus.

A small portion of it — about two acres — can still be used for housing because it won’t be part of Amazon’s campus. But Plaxall hasn’t decided if it wants apartments or office space there, and either way, it won’t be able to accommodate nearly as many homes as originally planned.

Meanwhile, another developer, TF Cornerstone, was poised to build 1,000 apartments on a neighboring site owned by the city’s Economic Development Corporation, of which 250 units would have been affordable. That site, too, will be part of Amazon’s office campus.

A spokesman for Amazon confirmed there will be no housing in its Long Island City complex.

One of de Blasio’s primary goals as mayor is to build and preserve 300,000 homes for people of limited means. He recently pointed to that housing plan when asked if Amazon would strain New York City’s housing market, like the tech sector has strained San Francisco’s.

"The absolute difference between us and San Francisco is we believe in economic diversity, we believe in ensuring there's a vast supply of affordable housing," he said.

Affordable housing, however, is no longer the main focus of development in Anable Basin.

The New York City Economic Development Corporation, which is helping shepherd the Amazon project, said the jobs and other amenities the company plans to bring will produce a net benefit for the area.

"Tackling the affordability crisis means building more affordable housing — but it also means creating more good-paying jobs," EDC spokesperson Stephanie Baez said. "Development of commercial office space around Anable Basin will offset concerns about residential overdevelopment that have been expressed by some community residents."

She said the plan will include other perks, like a workforce program and a public school.

On Thursday, TF Cornerstone circulated a job posting for a project manager for Amazon’s Long Island City campus, who will help build out “commercial development for Amazon along the Long Island City Waterfront.”

No salary is listed.

“The more we learn about this deal, the worse it gets,” Gianaris said.

THE BUZZ: First things first: Donald Trump is finally coming to pay his California wildfire respects. The commander-in-chief is scheduled to touch down Saturday and then meet with victims — a first despite a year of record-breakingly bad blazes. This comes after the feds and Gov. Jerry Brown have tried to move past Trump’s unsettling fire-related broadsides.

-- Back in California politics land: Democrat Katie Porter officially beat GOP Rep. Mimi Walters last night, which means Dems have won five of their targeted House races. While we’re still waiting for the final contest to be called, in CA-39, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is already breaking down its victory.

Story Continued Below

-- A new D-trip memo breaks down how the national party’s strategic focus on California — which included intervening to winnow a crowded primary field, opening a campaign office in Orange County and spending some $12.9 million on six targeted California races — yielded at least five pickups, with one more potentially coming. (The only Republican to survive a major onslaught, Rep. David Valadao, has seen his margin dwindle this week as the vote count has continued.) Even with the reach seats (Nunes, Hunter, McClintock) retained by the GOP, the DCCC can fairly boast it painted California’s House delegation blue. Some points from the memo:

-- The DCCC sought to get ahead of the top-two primary’s tricky dynamics and the attendant threat of Democrats fracturing the vote at the start of 2018, using data to determine and boost the strongest Dems (Gil Cisneros in the 39th and Harley Rouda in the 48th) and the weakest Republicans. They’re gleeful about boosting the “unsalvageable” Republican Diane Harkey, who lost badly to Democrat Mike Levin in the race for Rep. Darrell Issa’s seat (the DCCC worked to keep the more-electable state Assemblyman Rocky Chavez out of the general).

-- The work started early: The DCCC said it had people on the ground weeks after Trump’s inauguration and began running ads on health care back in 2017.

-- GOTV: The party spent $30 million this cycle to turn out voters, signed up 20,000 voters and called 6 million voters in targeted districts. They also invested in Spanish-language media to galvanize the Latino electorate.

-- Record-breaking fundraising numbers posted by prime candidates reflected party assistance, per the DCCC, which furnished digital fundraising experts.

THE GOP TAKE: Shawn Steel, the Republican National Committee’s man in California, tries to break down the tsunami that just hit the state GOP: “California Republicans, long in the wilderness, have now reached the point of desperation.” Steel points to structural and strategic problems that precede Donald Trump: Column .

BUENOS DÍAS, Good FRIDAY morning. San Francisco, Oakland and Sacramento schools are closed today because the air quality is so bad from the fires, and Facebook is moving once again into damage-control mode.

QUOTE OF THE DAY: “Come on in! The water is warm.” Rep. Nancy Pelosi on a speakership challenge from Rep. Marcia Fudge

TWEET OF THE DAY: Former First Lady Maria Shriver @MariaShriver with the preemptive POTUS warning: “I hope when @realDonaldTrump comes to CA he doesn’t try to lecture or shame us. Instead, I hope @realDonaldTrump shows gratitude to our firefighters, first responders and all those stepping up to help their fellow Californians. Tell us the money we need to rebuild is on the way. If not, don’t come.”

-- Where’s Jerry? Nothing official announced.

-- Where’s Gavin? Nothing official announced.

CALIFORNIA ON FIRE

UPDATES:

CAMP FIRE (Butte County) -- 141,000 acres, 40 percent contained. The death toll rose to 63, and 631 people are missing.

WOOLSEY FIRE (Los Angeles, Malibu) -- 93,682 acres, 62 percentcontained

-- “After Camp Fire, cops patrol a ruined Paradise: ‘There’s really no one to watch over,’” by SFChronicle’s Lizzie Johnson: Story .

That’s why people are doing this, because they know people depend on it. It gives you hope that people appreciate newspapers in a time like this.” -- David Little, editor of the Chico Enterprise-Record. Story .

MEOW: “‘Something beautiful amid total disaster.’ The Camp Fire and the salvation of London the cat” by SacBee’s Ryan Sabalow: Story .

-- “Americans Are Moving Closer to Nature, and Into Fire Zones” by NYT’s Kendra Pierre-Louis and Jeremy White: “The deadly wildfires that are devastating communities in parts of Northern and Southern California first ignited in an expanding part of the American landscape: not in forests, not in cities, but in the areas that experts call the wildland-urban interface. It is the transition zone between wildlands — such as forests, grasslands and scrublands — and human development.” Story .

It’s FRIDAY -- Got a tip? Feedback News to share? Let us know.

TOP TALKERS



FACEBOOK BACKLASH: “Facebook reconsiders Washington approach after Times reveals hardball tactics” by POLITICO’s Steven Overly and Ashley Gold: “Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg vowed to cut ties with ‘D.C.-type firms’ as his company fought to escape yet another bout of furor, this time surrounding its efforts to contain the damage from Russian election interference and consumer privacy violations.” Story .

SPEAKERSHIP DRAMA: “Pelosi's campaign for speaker hits snag as potential challenger emerges” by POLITICO’s Rachael Bade and Nolan D. McCaskill: “Former Congressional Black Caucus Chairwoman Marcia Fudge of Ohio told the Cleveland Plain Dealer that she is considering a bid for the gavel. CALIFORNIA BACKING: Californians rallied behind their colleague. Rep. Karen Bass had been floated by dissident Rep. Spokespeople for fellow Democratic Reps.-elect Harley Rouda and Josh Harder did not respond to questions about where the incoming members stand.





THE MIDTERMS

PORTER TAKES CA-45: The victory suggested by Democrat Katie Porter's steadily growing lead over Rep. Mimi Walters became official Thursday night: Porter prevailed, with a 6,203-vote lead when the AP called it. The win extends Democratic dominance in Orange County , where Republicans have been going all-out to forestall losses:

-- “Republicans Walters and Kim adopt Trump tactic of charging vote fraud with no evidence of wrongdoing” by LATimes’ Michael Finnegan: “Neither GOP Rep. Mimi Walters nor Republican candidate Young Kim has produced evidence to back up their charges that Democrats are trying to steal the election.” Story .

-- The Walters camp enlisted Newt Gingrich’s help in warning of potential election chicanery on the eve of defeat yesterday, blasting out a plea from the former House Speaker imploring supporters to donate and help Walters hold on. “Fighting back to keep this election fair is going to take everything we've got,” the email said.

CAREFUL WHAT YOU WISH FOR: “The Blue Wave Brought With it a Candidate Dems Might Prefer to Leave Adrift” by Voice of SD’s Jesse Marx: “Mike Schaefer’s likely win on the Board of Equalization shows there can be a downside for parties that win wave elections: Those waves can also usher in candidates the party wants to distance itself from.” Story .

-- “My turn: Confessions of a volunteer in Congressional District 10” by Andy Furillo for CALmatters: “I’ll admit it – I let Donald Trump get into my head, and I couldn’t get him out. -- SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION: Tony Thurmond's lead over Marshall Tuck shrank slightly to 82,696.

-- AD-16: Republican state Assemblywoman Catharine Baker’s lead diminished further to 159 votes.





THE TRUMP ERA

KHANNA VS. WALMART: Rep. Ro Khanna has already established a reputation as a progressive crusader and potential model of the Democratic Party’s leftward future. Having already played a role in pushing Amazon to raise its wages, the Silicon Valley Democrat announced yesterday that he and Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) were introducing legislation compelling Wal-Mart to pay its employees better — and explicitly linked the two.





GAVINLAND

-- “California's new governor embodies Democrats' dilemma on single payer” by POLITICO Pro Health’s Victoria Colliver: “Newsom is an avowed single-payer supporter in the country’s most populous state. But how much of his stand is principle and how much is policy is not totally clear. And no matter how he handles it, he'll inevitably anger part of his base.” Story .

2020 WATCH

-- “Influential president of Human Rights Campaign stepping down,” by the AP’s Julie Pace: “Sen. Kamala Harris, who has worked closely with [Chad] Griffin, praised his leadership of the nation’s largest gay rights advocacy group through a time of enormous change for the LGBT community … A prolific fundraiser with deep political ties, Griffin probably will become one of the most sought after advisers for Democrats preparing to undertake White House campaigns.” Story

CROWDED FIELD: “Note to Democrats pondering a presidential run: The clock is already ticking” by LATimes’ Evan Halper: “There are multiple Californians, multiple New Yorkers, multiple Massachusettsans, multiple African Americans, lots and lots of women. The pie is going to get carved up quickly into small slices.” Story .

ANOTHER ONE FROM CALIFORNIA – Author, lecturer and spiritual teacher Marianne Williamson, who made an unsuccessful bid for Congress in CA-33 in 2014, has announced on her website she’s formed an exploratory committee to run for president. The announcement by the progressive author has some Democrats — already worried about the kind of ammunition that attorney Michael Avenatti hands to Trump — wringing their hands. “Did you see her YouTube?,’’ one leading political analyst texted. “It’s like a cold open for SNL.”





CALIFORNIA AND THE CAPITOL CORRIDOR

-- "A Californian is the top Republican in the House. Can his party recover back home?" by McClatchy's Emily Cadei: "Three years after he first bid for the job, Bakersfield Rep. Kevin McCarthy has finally landed the top Republican leadership position in the House of Representatives. But for the six-term congressman, the circumstances are less than ideal." Story

WATCHING: “After FBI raid, L.A. Councilman Jose Huizar is stripped of his committee assignments” by LATimes’ David Zahniser and Emily Alpert Reyes: “Huizar has been under tremendous legal pressure in recent weeks.” Story .

OFF THE RAILS: California’s beleaguered high-speed rail project was dealt another blow yesterday as the state auditor released a blistering reporting concluding that the High Speed Rail Authority’s “flawed decision making” around the start of construction and “poor contract management for a wide range of high-value contracts have contributed to billions of dollars in cost overruns for completing the system.” Read it here , and here is the HSR Authority’s response .

-- While Brown has championed the project, Gov.-elect Gavin Newsom has echoed other elected Democrats in expressing qualified support and saying he would focus on a scaled-back rail plan that prioritizes the Central Valley leg while the southern portion is an “open-ended question.”

A NOTE ON TECH MIDTERM SPENDING — According to a recent Washington Post report , top executives at Apple, Facebook, Google and Microsoft donated relatively little to congressional campaigns during the 2018 midterm elections. But there's at least one notable outlier: Microsoft President Brad Smith gave over $100,000 in political contributions this past cycle. title: CBC MEMBERS BACK PELOSI OVER FUDGE -- House Dem majority expands -- TRUMP NONCOMMITTAL ON SHUTDOWN -- Senate GOP urges Trump to nominate an attorney general soon
content: By Nolan D. McCaskill ( nmccaskill@politico.com or @NolanDMcCaskill ) CBC MEMBERS STAND WITH PELOSI -- Many members of the Congressional Black Caucus are standing by their commitments to support Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) for speaker on the House… [+14968 chars]
fulltext:
CBC MEMBERS BACK PELOSI OVER FUDGE -- House Dem majority expands -- TRUMP NONCOMMITTAL ON SHUTDOWN -- Senate GOP urges Trump to nominate an attorney general soon

By Nolan D. McCaskill ( nmccaskill@politico.com or @NolanDMcCaskill )

CBC MEMBERS STAND WITH PELOSI -- Many members of the Congressional Black Caucus are standing by their commitments to support Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) for speaker on the House floor, despite the possibility that former CBC Chairwoman Marcia Fudge (D-Ohio) could enter the race. “The CBC has been spoiling to elevate a group member into one of the top two positions in Democratic leadership for years, with current CBC Chairman Cedric Richmond writing as recently as two weeks ago that having a black speaker or majority leader was a top priority,” Rachael, Bres and I write. “But in interviews with eight CBC members about Fudge’s possible bid for speaker, all but two members said they would back Pelosi over Fudge.”

Story Continued Below

For his part, Richmond told reporters he’d likely be on “Team Marcia” if she launched a bid for speaker. “And the Louisiana Democrat predicted that his fellow CBC members currently backing Pelosi over Fudge would change their tune should she actually jump into the race,” we note. Fudge, Richmond said, “would be a good speaker. I’m not anti-Pelosi, but whatever Marcia does, I’m very pro-Marcia.” Pelosi invited -- if not dared -- Fudge to challenge her. Fudge is among the group of 17 anti-Pelosi Democrats who have pledged to vote against her on the House floor. “Come on in,” Pelosi said. “The water’s warm.” More: https://politi.co/2Q23pjZ

Related: “‘Where are we recognized?’: Fudge emerges as potential challenger to Pelosi,” by The Washington Post’s Robert Costa and Elise Viebeck: https://wapo.st/2DHBgJi ; “Marcia Fudge, Toying With Speaker Run, Slams Nancy Pelosi,” from HuffPost’s Matt Fuller: http://bit.ly/2QMCvK5 ; and “Pelosi allies rage over tactics of opponents,” via The Hill’s Scott Wong and Mike Lillis: http://bit.ly/2zZJS9A

DEMS GET TWO MORE PICKUPS -- The House Democratic majority continues to grow. Democrat Katie Porter defeated Rep. Mimi Walters (R-Calif.) last night. “Walters’ loss means the GOP is in danger of not having a single representative in Congress from Orange County, a former Republican stronghold once home to Presidents Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan,” Brent D. Griffiths writes. “After leading in election night returns, Walters was reportedly mounting a bid to head House Republicans’ campaign arm, the National Republican Congressional Committee, before her lead began to shrink and then evaporate.” More: https://politi.co/2Fs6gid

Democrat Jared Golden also claimed victory Thursday over Rep. Bruce Poliquin (R-Maine), who has sued the Maine secretary of state over the constitutionality of the vote. The contest in the 2nd Congressional District is the first House race to be decided by a ranked-choice voting system. Poliquin said he “won the constitutional ‘one-person, one-vote’ first choice election on Election Day” and “will proceed with our constitutional concerns about the rank vote algorithm.” “Under Maine’s system, voters rank their preferred candidates to allow for an ‘instant runoff’ by counting second-choice votes from people who supported last-placed candidates, repeating the process until a candidate secures victory with more than 50 percent of the vote,” Elena Schneider explains. More: https://politi.co/2RRqSBI

SHUTDOWN WATCH -- President Donald Trump made no commitments about avoiding a partial government shutdown in three weeks if Democrats fail to give him sufficient funds for his border wall, according to Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Richard Shelby (R-Ala.). Shelby was among the group of Senate Republicans who met with the president at the White House on Thursday. Shelby told reporters Trump didn’t say “I’m going to keep the government open” but seemed to agree that a shutdown should be avoided. “Trump’s staff has warned him he may not get the full $5 billion he has demanded for new wall construction for 2019,” The Washington Post’s Erica Werner and Damian Paletta report.

“GOP leaders this fall convinced Trump to delay any decision about the border wall until after the November midterm elections, fearful that a big showdown could hurt Republicans with voters,” they continue. “But Republicans suffered heavy losses during the midterms in the House of Representatives and will lose control of that chamber in early January. Although they retain full control of Congress for now, Republicans still need support from Democrats to pass any bill in the Senate. Democrats have expressed opposition to giving Trump the money he wants to build his long-promised wall.” More: https://wapo.st/2Kcgq5i

HAPPY FRIDAY! Thanks for reading Huddle, the play-by-play guide to all things Capitol Hill, on this Nov. 16.

THURSDAY’S MOST CLICKED: Roll Call’s report on House Republicans considering changing the way they select committee leaders was the winner.

SENATE GOP NUDGES TRUMP FOR AG NOMINEE -- Senate Republicans are urging the president to nominate a permanent attorney general -- and fast. Republicans are hopeful that the nomination of a new DOJ chief “will blunt bipartisan concern over the future of special counsel Robert Mueller and boost the GOP ahead of tough government funding talks,” Burgess and Eliana Johnson report. Most Republicans insist the president won’t oust Mueller or derail his investigation. But they acknowledge an AG nominee would halt momentum for legislation to protect Mueller and mollify Democrats who are adamant that acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker will undermine the probe.

“The White House is working to find a broadly acceptable pick for the job,” they write. Potential candidates include former Attorney General Bill Barr and former Deputy Attorney General Mark Filip. Trump, however, has no relationship with either candidate, and allies say the difficulty in nominating one of them lies in persuading the president that he can trust them. “Absent a pledge from [former Attorney General Jeff] Sessions’ successor to lay off Mueller, any nominee would be enormously difficult to confirm and would quickly turn off the prospect of Democratic support,” they add. Regardless of who the president picks -- or when -- a nominee likely won’t get confirmed until next year. More: https://politi.co/2Fqe8ka

Related reads: “AP source: Whitaker told Graham that Mueller probe to go on,” by The Associated Press’ Mary Clare Jalonick and Mike Balsamo: http://bit.ly/2DpuiYn ; and “Republicans aren’t following Flake on threat of judicial nominee blockade over Mueller protection bill,” from CNN’s Jeremy Herb and Ted Barrett: https://cnn.it/2TgvF0S

TRUMP VS. COTTON -- Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) is ramping up his opposition to a bipartisan, Trump-backed criminal justice overhaul. “Cotton on Thursday stepped up his public potshots at what he’s called a ‘jailbreak’ proposal -- a counter-campaign that one fellow senator believes came at the request of Majority Leader Mitch McConnell,” Elana, Burgess and Eliana Johnson write. “The hawkish Cotton also published an op-ed slamming the compromise and needled Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), the chief author of the criminal justice compromise, with a push for a public hearing on the legislation -- a version of which already has passed Grassley’s committee.”

Cotton doesn’t formally oppose the legislation because he hasn’t seen the text. However, he said the House’s narrower version of the bill “had problems” but set a more achievable mark. The proposal has “moved consistently to the left in the Senate, even though it didn’t have to,” Cotton told reporters. “I don’t think it’s going to have much support from Republicans in the Senate.” “Proponents of the Senate deal see the current lame-duck session as their best chance for success on a revamp that senior members of both parties have spent years negotiating, given the prospect that next year’s Democratic House could change the dynamics of the talks,” they add. More: https://politi.co/2S2Qrjt

Related: “Booker throws his weight behind Trump-backed criminal justice deal,” via Elana: https://politi.co/2DI0AyC ; and “Whitaker told Trump he has concerns over sentencing reform bill,” per The Washington Post’s Josh Dawsey and Seung Min Kim: https://wapo.st/2FsNlDL

HYDE-SMITH UNDER FIRE AGAIN -- Another video has surfaced showing Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith making controversial comments at a campaign stop. “And then they remind me that there’s a lot of liberal folks in those other schools who ... maybe we don’t want to vote,” she says in the clip. “Maybe we want to make it just a little more difficult. And I think that’s a great idea.” A spokeswoman said Hyde-Smith was “obviously” joking and claimed “the video was selectively edited.” The release of the latest clip follows Sunday’s release of a video in which she apparently jokes about attending a “public hanging.”

A spokesman for Democrat Mike Espy, her opponent, said Hyde-Smith is a “walking stereotype who embarrasses our state.” “For a state like Mississippi, where voting rights were obtained through sweat and blood, everyone should appreciate that this is not a laughing matter,” Espy spokesman Danny Blanton said. Hyde-Smith and Espy are competing in a Nov. 27 runoff. More: https://nbcnews.to/2FCtfXZ

BLACKBURN COULD JOIN JUDICIARY COMMITTEE -- Sen.-elect Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.) is favored to join the Judiciary Committee, a panel whose Republican members are all men. No decision on Blackburn’s committee assignments has been made yet, as the upper chamber is weeks away from determining committee slots. “Senate Republicans are eager to address their gender diversity issues,” Burgess writes. “Sen. Joni Ernst of Iowa was just elected to the leadership team ... and leaders want a female senator on the Judiciary Committee. In previous years, it’s been difficult to convince female senators to join the panel, according to Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley.” More: https://politi.co/2FzlDFg

Related read: “Cortez Masto named DSCC chair,” from Burgess: https://politi.co/2TiELdN

HOUSE GOP RULES -- House Republicans adopted an amendment to conference rules that would prevent members who are seeking higher office from keeping their leadership posts. A spokesman for Rep. Elise Stefanik (R-N.Y.), who introduced the amendment, called it “a commonsense proposal to ensure House Republican leaders are focused on advancing our legislative agenda.” “GOP sources said there were some grievances within the party last year over Rep. Luke Messer (R-Ind.) launching his Indiana Senate bid shortly after obtaining the position of GOP policy chair,” The Hill’s Juliegrace Brufke reports. “He ended up losing in the Senate GOP primary earlier this year.” More: http://bit.ly/2A7vNr5

Related: “GOP leader concedes ‘we have room for improvement’ on House diversity,” by Caitlin Oprysko: https://politi.co/2QLEQ84 ; and “GOP approves rule for Don Young,” from The Hill’s Juliegrace Brufke: http://bit.ly/2PYyhlw

AOC, PALLONE TUSSLE OVER CLIMATE CHANGE -- Rep.-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and other incoming freshmen fought with incoming Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Frank Pallone (D-N.J.) in a closed-door caucus meeting Thursday. Pallone, who was backed by some of his committee members, “slammed the creation of the new climate panel,” Anthony Adragna, Bres and Zack Colman report. “Pallone argued that his committee and other existing panels within the House could take on the issue aggressively. But Ocasio-Cortez (N.Y.), Rep.-elect Joe Neguse (Colo.) and some of the other progressive incoming lawmakers fought back, saying they ran on the issue and needed to do it.”

Ocasio-Cortez tweeted that she had no direct interaction with Pallone, who declined to comment on what occurred behind closed doors. He did, however, explain his opposition. “My fear is that if you have a select committee, by the time the select committee gets going, gets appointed and hires staff that it might actually delay what we’re doing,” Pallone told reporters. “We’ve got people who are in charge of these committees who are very progressive and I just don’t see the need for the select committee. I think it may actually delay what the progressives are trying to achieve.” More: https://politi.co/2FrvtsP

Related: “Ocasio-Cortez’s ‘Green New Deal’ becomes flash point for Pelosi,” via Zack Colman and Anthony Adragna: https://politi.co/2ThaMmp ; and “Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s first days in Congress: Treated as intern, clothing criticized,” per USA Today’s Christal Hayes: http://bit.ly/2PXV1C4

2020 WATCH -- Sen. Bob Casey (D-Pa.) isn’t running. He’s not even actively entertaining a White House run. But he also isn’t ruling one out. “If Casey begins to seriously pursue a run, he would join as many as nine fellow Democratic senators, who are considering their own 2020 presidential primary campaigns,” Elana writes. “Casey said his party’s presidential primary in the race against Trump ‘might be the biggest field ever’ and urged his party to discuss the ‘lessons we can draw’ from the midterms. But he reiterated that ‘I wouldn’t’ go so far as to say he is considering a run, even if not actively.” More: https://politi.co/2BbvcpW

TRANSITIONS -- Matt House has left Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer’s (D-N.Y.) office, where he served as communications director.

Samuel Beaver has started as a director of government relations at the National Association of Manufacturers. He most recently was policy adviser for Sen. John Cornyn’s (R-Texas) whip office.

TODAY’S TRIVIA -- From Brian Smith: This outgoing congressman is the great-great-great-nephew of a former Whig vice-presidential nominee. Who is the congressman, and who is the former nominee? The first person to correctly guess gets a mention in the next edition of Huddle. Send your best guess my way: nmccaskill@politico.com .

title: Murphy goes through rough period as storm brings commuters to full stop
content: Presented by New Jersey Charter Schools Association Good Friday morning! I hope your commute wasnt too terrible Thursday night. Gov. Phil Murphy will be hearing about this one for a while. The state was woefully unprepared. It was a nightmare for people on th… [+21351 chars]
fulltext:
Murphy goes through rough period as storm brings commuters to full stop

Good Friday morning!

I hope your commute wasn’t too terrible Thursday night. Gov. Phil Murphy will be hearing about this one for a while.

Story Continued Below

The state was woefully unprepared . It was a nightmare for people on the roads. Those who relied on mass transit didn’t fare well either. It wasn’t just New Jersey. The entire tri-state area was a disaster. But New Jerseyans aren’t going to allow the governor that excuse, even if the forecasts underestimated how much precipitation would fall as snow and ice, instead of rain.

If the state doesn’t over-prepare for these things, the governor suffers the political consequences. And local officials will probably have to face their own constituents wondering why they stayed in Atlantic City Thursday for the League. It doesn’t matter whether their presence would have made a difference. People want them to see it first-hand.

It was roughly at this same point in his first term that then-Gov. Chris Christie went to Disney World as the state got slammed by a severe snowstorm (Murphy’s communications director made sure to remind Christie of that). The public forgave him. But nobody forgot. Christie went through ihs own traffic misery yesterday, tweeting at Murphy about his own 13-mile commute that took nearly six hours and even calling WKXW-FM about it. (The replies to Christie’s tweet are about what you would expect).

WHERE’S MURPHY? Winter storm press conference in Fords at 10:30am.

HAPPY BIRTHDAY — Comms consultant Tony Ciavolella, BPU’s Ilene Lampitt, consultant Shai Goldstein. Saturday for state Sen. Nicholas Sacco, state Assemblywoman BettyLou DeCroce. Sunday for state Sen. Nicholas Scuatri, New Jersey Future’s Missy Rebovich, Westampton Mayor John Wisniewski

WHAT TRENTON MADE

MURPHY SHOULD AVOID USING FAVORITE PHRASE ‘FULL STOP’ FOR A WHILE — “New Jersey commuters wanted snow plows, Phil Murphy gave them excuses and a lame video,” by The Record’s Charles Stile: “Gov. Phil Murphy beams with the belief that his toothy smile and can-do optimism can melt his most ardent foes. Not on Thursday, when a stronger-than-expected storm turned the afternoon commute into a white-knuckled slog along un-plowed highways glazed with ice. At least 500 vehicles collided in accidents. Bus commuters found themselves locked out of the Port Authority's NYC bus terminal. Suddenly, no one had any patience for Smiling Phil. And they weren't buying his excuses. His public service video, with its oddly, out-of-sync and cozy Winter Wonderland backdrop, and opening with a hokey ‘Hey, Governor Phil Murphy coming at ya" failed to reassure anyone who listened.’ His urging to stay home and be safe struck, only fueled commuter fury. And no one really was all that interested in his finger pointing at forecasters who, he said, underestimated the scope of the storm, a theme Murphy pushed in an early-evening blitz of radio and television interviews.” Read more here

LOOK ON THE BRIGHT SIDE: AT LEAST YOU WEREN’T STUCK IN THE PORT AUTHORITY — “Port Authority closes doors, thousands told to find another way home as roads remain icy nightmares,” by NJ Advance Media’s Sophie Nieto-Munoz: “Port Authority officials threw their hands in the air early Thursday night and told commuters packed into the bus terminal that they should try to find another way home as buses remained helplessly stuck in hours of tri-state gridlock. Then they closed the doors to the whole thing, and suggested people try to catch a train or hop on a ferry.” Read more here

Phil Murphy took thinly veiled shots at former Gov. Chris Christie in a major speech Thursday, telling an audience of local leaders from across the state that he’s “undoing, bit by bit, the poor decisions of the past that were made in the name of political ambition.” In remarks to delegates at the State League of Municipalities Conference, the first he has attended as governor, Murphy said “the name-calling” was being left behind and said he was making smarter decisions for the state than past administrations. He said he was replacing past policies with “sound ones.” “A moneyball mindset plus good intentions — instead of endless political shenanigans — lead to sustained economic growth,” Murphy said after announcing the state has its lowest unemployment rate in 17 years. “That mindset is something I promised you when I was here last year. Joseph Vitale says he’s leaning toward supporting legislation that would legalize recreational marijuana, a turnaround that would give Senate President Steve Sweeney a much-needed ‘yes’ vote as he works to gather support for a bill that’s expected to be heard in committee in less than two weeks. “The more that I think about it, it’s a game changer for our state and everyone in it. I think there are some arguments being made on both sides of the debate, and I agree with most of the points of the folks who support it,” said Vitale (D-Middlesex), who has previously opposed legalization efforts. Vitale told POLITICO he still has concerns about the possibility of minors having greater access to the drug if it’s legalized, but “on balance, I might support“ legalization. The Union question won a narrower-than-expected victory, 54%-46%, in the deeply-blue town.” Read more here

The victims of a deadly adenovirus outbreak were in such severe medical distress that it was already too late to save them, according to an emergency room doctor. ‘Both were in irreversible shock upon arrival,’ recalled Dr. Frank Briglia, who manages the pediatric emergency room where the two boys were taken. The illness that has rampaged through the pediatrics ward of the 92-bed Wanaque Center for Nursing and Rehabilitation in Haskell targeted the ‘medically fragile,’ those children on ventilators with compromised immune systems, who had significant health problems. So far, 10 children have died and 23 others have been infected.” Read more here .

JOBS — New Jersey’s unemployment drops to 4.1 percent, a 17-year low, by POLITICO’s Katherine Landergan: New Jersey’s unemployment rate dropped to 4.1 percent in October, the lowest rate since June 2001, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The jobless rate had been 4.2 percent in September. But Gov Phil Murphy said there’s still work to be done, including raising the minimum wage over a period of years to $15 an hour. Lawmakers are currently negotiating a bill and Assembly Speaker Craig Coughlin says he thinks he can get legislation to the governor’s desk by January. Read more here .

CHRISTIE WOULD NEVER DO SOMETHING THAT CONTRADICTED HIS PREVIOUS STATEMENTS TO BENEFIT HIMSELF POLITICALLY — “Trump launches Twitter rant against Mueller. Does that hurt Christie's chances at AG?” by The Record’s Charles Stile: “If you haven't noticed by now, President Trump really, really hates Bob Mueller, the special counsel investigating possible Russian collusion with his 2016 presidential campaign. But Chris Christie, the former New Jersey governor, really likes Mueller. Christie could be a prime candidate for president of the Bob Mueller fan club. "I always found Bob Mueller to be a person of integrity and honesty and hard worker and he deserves great credit for the fact that there has been absolutely no leaking out of that operation," Christie said Wednesday after an appearance at the New Jersey League of Municipalities convention in Atlantic City. And why is this difference in opinion significant? It's because Christie's name has been floated as a short-list candidate for Trump's next attorney general. Trump fired Jeff Sessions last week, a day after the midterm elections, reportedly furious that Sessions removed himself from oversight of Mueller's probe … If Trump plans to pursue this Nixonian-strategy, then why would he install a fan of Mueller, like Christie, whose admiration of Mueller stems for their work together in the early 2000s at the Justice Department? ‘I have no idea,’ Christie said when asked if his praise of Mueller will be a disqualifier.” Read more here

CLIMATE STATUS: HOSTILE — “Ocasio-Cortez gets in closed-door fight with veteran lawmaker over climate change,” by POLITICO’s Anthony Adragna, John Bresnahan and Zack Colman: “A fight broke out in a closed-door meeting of House Democrats over climate change as a powerful veteran lawmaker fought with freshman star Rep.-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and other members-elect over the creation of a special panel for the issue. New Jersey Rep. Frank Pallone, incoming chairman of the powerful Energy and Commerce Committee — backed by a number of other committee members — slammed the creation of the new climate panel, according to multiple sources in the room. Pallone argued that his committee and other existing panels within the House could take on the issue aggressively. But Ocasio-Cortez (N.Y.), Rep.-elect Joe Neguse (Colo.) and some of the other progressive incoming lawmakers fought back, saying they ran on the issue and needed to do it … Pallone declined to comment on what happened during the closed-door meeting, but further explained why he opposes the select committee. ‘My fear is that if you have a select committee, by the time the select committee gets going, gets appointed and hires staff that it might actually delay what we’re doing,’ the New Jersey Democrat told reporters.” Read more here

Booker's support for the carefully-crafted agreement to overhaul prison and sentencing laws also puts him in rare alignment with a president whom he's openly considering challenging in 2020. fulltext:
NEW REP’s social media incites attacks on MADIGAN — HOW J.B. won — and SCHAKOWSKY’s mayoral endorsement Presented by the Illinois Car Sharing Coalition

TGIF, Illinois. I’m one of those who decorates for the holidays before Thanksgiving--so I don’t have to worry about it after. But before I pull out boxes, there's news.

THE BUZZ

Commenters on state Rep.-elect Anne Stava-Murray‘s Facebook page have for weeks been disparaging House Speaker Mike Madigan. That’s no surprise given Democrat Stava-Murray campaigned saying she wouldn’t vote to re-elect Madigan as speaker. But some of the social-media rhetoric has gone over the top, including inciting violence. Of Madigan, one commenter wrote, “Can’t we just drag him out into the street and beat him within an inch of his life…” Another said “Throw the bastard out through a window about six floors up maybe he will get the hint it’s time to go.”

Story Continued Below

Stava-Murray told POLITICO she doesn’t delete comments because “it’s illegal to do so” if they’re from constituents. She didn’t push back to condemn the comments either because she said she didn’t see them. Stava-Murray, who is manager of the Facebook page, said she only looks at the comments at the top of the feed when she logs on. It wasn’t until after talking to POLITICO that she responded to the “beat him” comment, writing, “Let’s try to keep it peaceful. Not trying to invite violence here, just phone calls to reps.”

That may be enough to calm concerns by anyone who saw the posts that Stava-Murray takes her social-media messaging seriously.

The newly elected Rep has been calling lawmakers and encouraging them to vote against Madigan as speaker. Stava-Murray says it’s what her constituents want. She sending a message that a change in leadership is necessary given complaints last year about sexual harassment on Capitol Hill.

Legislators aren't clamoring to join her parade. Madigan also has been calling lawmakers and asking they vote for him as speaker. That prompted Stava-Murray to post a Facebook message to constituents. “I’m asking people to call their legislator to ask them to reconsider” their support of Madigan. The vote is taken up by lawmakers Jan. 9.

Stava-Murray, who has most recently served as a commissioner of the Naperville Board of Fire and Police, narrowly defeated state Rep. David Olsen, a Downers Grove resident who had served as a village commissioner and College of DuPage board member and vice chairman.

MORE BUZZ

The best campaign money can buy: J.B. Pritzker’s campaign didn’t just surpass fundraising expectations. It was an “unprecedented” application of science and innovation “at every level.” POLITICO’s Natasha Korecki got a behind-the-scenes look at the operation. What she uncovered is startling. title: CUOMO flip-flops on state process for AMAZON deal — AMAZON site would have become affordable housing — DE BLASIO rolls out a new plan for NYCHA — SNOWVEMBER leads to finger-pointing — FELDER won’t meet with GOP
content: Presented by Airbnb If the Cuomo and de Blasio administrations were thinking that the Amazon deal would meet with universal acclaim, their praises sung by the choirs of civic angels well, they guessed wrong. And now Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio … [+19007 chars]
fulltext:
CUOMO flip-flops on state process for AMAZON deal — AMAZON site would have become affordable housing — DE BLASIO rolls out a new plan for NYCHA — SNOWVEMBER leads to finger-pointing — FELDER won’t meet with GOP Presented by Airbnb

If the Cuomo and de Blasio administrations were thinking that the Amazon deal would meet with universal acclaim, their praises sung by the choirs of civic angels — well, they guessed wrong.

And now Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio find themselves fighting on the same side, as critics from the New York Times to the City Council question the wisdom of handing a trillion-dollar company more than $2 billion in incentives. The governor dismissed the voices of dissent, saying their arguments are “nonsensical.”

“This is the largest economic infusion the state has ever seen,’ Cuomo said. ‘It’s a big, transformative move for our economy in the tech sector. It diversifies our economy, and it’s a home run. … These are great jobs.”

That’s their argument, and they’re sticking with it. But as our Dana Rubinstein notes, there seems to be some dispute on the Capitol’s second floor about some of that incentive money.

Dana writes: “Twenty-four hours after the administration confirmed its plan to award Amazon up to $505 million in grants for its new Queens headquarters would require the approval of the Public Authorities Control Board — an obscure state entity over which the Legislature has some authority — the administration walked it back. In interviews with the New York Daily News and The New York Times Thursday, Cuomo budget director Robert Mujica said that in the case of the $505 million grant, the state could evade board approval, thereby denying the state Legislature a say in the matter. A spokesman for Mujica confirmed Thursday night that was the state’s new opinion.”

More broadly, Cuomo and de Blasio, who have argued over the meaning of progressivism at a time when the Democratic Party is listing to the port side, find themselves having to defend the sort of deal they might well have railed against had it been negotiated by, say, Mike Bloomberg or some other corporate-political type.

It will pre-empt at least 1,500 units of affordable housing that were originally planned for the site, as Sally and Dana report today. It’s going to displace 1,000 public school employees who work in an office there. It’s part of a pattern of Mayor de Blasio saying one thing and doing another when it comes to real estate development, the Times’s J. David Goodman and Willie Neuman write today.

The corporate subsidies come at a time when the subways and the city’s public housing stock are literally crumbling, and as a newly-released study shows that two out of every five working-age New York City households do not have the income they need to pay for basic necessities, like food, housing, health care and child care.

But this is their deal, and they are in it together. If nothing else, it may make them feel more like teammates and less like sparring partners.That may not be such a bad thing.

WHAT CITY HALL IS READING

SNOWPOCALYPSE NOW: “A few inches of snow brought chaos and massive traffic to New York City roads on Thursday — prompting a storm of criticism for the city’s response to the wintry weather...The snowstorm barreled into the city on Thursday afternoon, and ended up dropping some 6 inches on the city at Central Park after the forecast originally called for about 1 to 3 inches. When asked about the turmoil, City Hall referred questions to the Sanitation Department — which on Wednesday said it had issued a “snow alert” to the “relevant city agencies” to be ready for the storm. ... In a statement, the department said it originally sent out some 700 salt spreaders, but “The afternoon snowfall was much heavier than had been forecast by all weather outlets requiring that we deploy plows.” It said, however, “complicating” matters were the closures of the George Washington Bridge and the Bayonne Bridge, which delayed plowing.” New York Post

PORT AUTHORITY PARADOX: “By 5:30 p.m., officials at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown Manhattan were advising commuters to take trains or ferries. With few buses able to get there, the terminal became so overcrowded that access to its second and third floors had to be blocked. The line of people waiting to get into the terminal stretched for a full block, all the way to Seventh Avenue.” New York Times’s Patrick McGeehan

“Newark's Penn Station was also a nightmare for many, packed wall to wall with exasperated commuters , who resorted to pushing and shoving amid the disorder and lack of communication. The Long Island Rail Road and New Jersey Transit also had systemwide delays.” NBC4 New York

“City students were left stranded on snow-stuck school buses late into the night Thursday — such as special-needs student George Jordan who spent seven hours on a bus home to the Bronx — after the day’s small storm clogged streets and caused havoc across New York. The Department of Education said on Twitter that there were still buses with kids heading home out on the roads after 11 p.m.” New York Post

— Nearly 150 trees went down across New York City.

NYCHA 2.0, the latest DE BLASIO NYCHA OVERHAUL: The de Blasio administration is preparing to overhaul its long-term approach to one of its most intractable problems — the crumbling public housing buildings that more than 400,000 New Yorkers call home. Officials from City Hall and the New York City Housing Authority, whose vast troubles are at the center of an ongoing federal case , have been briefing elected officials in recent weeks, ahead of unveiling a new 10-year plan to raise at least $22 billion for the agency. The blueprint, a revamp of a plan the city released in 2015 called NextGen NYCHA, seeks to raise revenue by monetizing the housing authority’s assets and partnering with private developers to manage dilapidated buildings, according to multiple sources briefed on the rollout...The plan, dubbed NYCHA 2.0, proposes that 62,000 of the agency's roughly 175,000 apartments be enrolled in one of several federal programs, primarily the Rental Assistance Demonstration or RAD, sources said. That’s more than triple the goal in the original plan. POLITICO’s Sally Goldenberg

LESS FOR MORE — by Dana: All is not well at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. If no substantial new money comes the MTA's way in the near future, the authority will have to cut service and raise subway fares as much as 15 percent by 2022, officials warned Thursday. That would be on top of the 4-to-5 percent subway-fare hikes the MTA is planning next spring and again in 2021. "[This] is the land of tough choices," said Andy Byford, who, as New York City Transit president, runs the system's subways and buses. In new proposals released Thursday, the MTA said it is considering raising the base subway fare from $2.75 to $3, and raising the cost of a 30-day pass from $121 to as much as $127. On MTA commuter rails, it's considering a maximum increase of nearly 4 percent on weekly and monthly tickets. And on its bridges and tunnels, the MTA is contemplating a toll hike of as much as 8 percent for E-ZPass users (who comprise the vast majority of bridge and tunnel customers). Meanwhile, to balance its budget next year, the MTA is considering eliminating employee wellness programs, slashing station painting contracts, cutting subway car cleaning and manual track inspections, diminishing fare evasion enforcement, eliminating some bus service to the Staten Island Ferry, and delaying the roll-out of two new faster bus service routes, known in transit-world jargon as Select Bus Service. Read more here.

TOP TALKER: ”The revelation that there could be significant fare increases or service reductions came after the news that Amazon was promised more than $2 billion in government incentives in exchange for locating a headquarters in Long Island City, Queens. The M.T.A. deficits have been caused in part by declining ridership, which has led to lower revenue projections. The decline is worrisome because it comes as the city’s population is increasing and tourism is booming.Officials blamed the ridership drop on competition from Uber and other ride-hail apps, and on construction work on nights and weekends to fix the system. Some riders said they had become fed up by constant delays and had abandoned the subway. The authority expects growing deficits of $510 million in 2020 and $816 million in 2021, said Robert E. Foran, the agency’s chief financial officer. Without new funding or huge service cuts, fares might have to rise by as much as 15 percent, he said.” New York Times’s Emma Fitzsimmons

MERRY CHRISTMAS: “With just weeks remaining in 2018, New York-Presbyterian is struggling to reach an agreement to remain in Empire BlueCross BlueShield's network. If the two sides can't agree before Jan. 1, New York-Presbyterian estimates that about 300,000 patients could face higher charges next year. New York-Presbyterian is informing patients about the status of negotiations through a letter and a new website, staywithnyp.org . The website states that "Empire/Anthem has demanded deep cuts that would slash more than $200 million in payments to New York-Presbyterian, all while the insurance giant generates billions in profits." Crain’s New York

WHAT ALBANY'S READING

FELDER TO SIT OUT GOP LEADERSHIP VOTE — “The state Senate’s diminished Republican conference will gather in the Capitol on Friday to decide whether Majority Leader John Flanagan should serve as minority leader in 2019, but one long-time member of the conference says he will not be joining them. “No,” said state Sen. Simcha Felder, when asked if he’d be there. Felder, a registered Democrat from Brooklyn who regularly runs on both major party lines, has conferenced with Republicans since he was elected in 2012. After the Independent Democratic Conference dissolved in April, calls for him to join with other members of his party intensified, as he was responsible for giving the 31 Republicans control of a chamber in which 32 members are needed for a majority.

But Felder steadfastly declined to do so, saying that the resulting change in leadership would lead to “an unprecedented and uncertain late session political battle that will only hurt my constituents and New Yorkers.” Democrats captured control of the Senate in last week's election and are poised to have at least 39 members in 2019, meaning Felder’s status as a king-maker has ended. But the state senator, who has always said that he is more interested in helping his constituents than any partisan loyalties, has now expressed at least some interest in joining the Democrats now that they control the spoils.” POLITICO’s Bill Mahoney

HOT COMPETITION FOR NO-POWER JOB — “Two Republican senators, including one from Western New York, are feverishly vying for a Senate leadership job with zero power in Albany over policy matters, the state budget or even parking lot assignments at the Capitol. Yet, senators John Flanagan of Long Island and Catharine Young from Olean, are coveting the right to be called Senate Minority Leader come January. That’s when the GOP turns over the keys of the Senate to the Democrats, who will have an overwhelming majority when they come into power: 40 members of their conference compared with 23 for Republicans. Flanagan, the current Senate Majority Leader, and Young, the head of the Senate GOP campaign finance committee, have been burning up their phone lines in a pitched battle against each other. The voters are the 21 other Senate Republicans who will be returning to Albany.” Buffalo News’ Tom Precious

NY SPENDS $4.8M MORE ON FILM HUB IN ‘FINAL DISCONNECT’ — “State taxpayers will fork over another $4.8 million to help seed a film industry in Syracuse, where New York has already spent more than $16 million on a film hub that is used only sporadically. That's it for state funding to help the film hub, declared Howard Zemsky, who heads the state economic development agency, Empire State Development. Onondaga County bought the film studio from the state for $1 earlier this year. ‘This is part of, really, the unwind for us at the film hub in Syracuse,’ Zemsky told ESD board members today. ‘We see this as kind of a final disconnect for us.’ Empire State Development today approved a $4.8 million grant to an affiliate of CNY Arts , a nonprofit arts funding group, to help finance films made in Syracuse.” Post-Standard’s Tim Knauss

ASSEMBLYWOMAN JENNE WANTS NEW LEADERSHIP AT DANC — HERSELF — Outgoing Assemblywoman Addie A.E. Jenne has sent a letter to Development Authority of the North Country board members stating there is a need for “immediate change” in DANC’s executive director position and asking that she be appointed to the job. The job is currently held by former state Sen. James W. Wright, who has been in the position since 2009. Ms. Jenne said Wednesday that the Nov. 6 election left Democrats in the majority of both the state Assembly and Senate, potentially making appointments to DANC’s board vulnerable to state control and leaving the board open to political interference. ‘My advocacy would be to retain local control,’ she said. ‘If the board is concerned about that, that is something I would have relevant experience in and be able to advocate on behalf of regional control.’” Watertown Daily Times’ Brian Kelly

CIMINELLI ALLIES PLEAD FOR LENIENCY — “In his years as a prominent Buffalo businessman, Louis Ciminelli made some enemies, but he made lots of friends, spreading his time and money around to cultural groups, providing steady union jobs on his many projects and enjoying close ties with politicians across party lines. Now, as Ciminelli faces a possible prison sentence being handed down in a couple weeks, those friends and family are coming to his defense. Lawyers for the convicted former construction titan have turned to dozens of big and small players in the Buffalo community to try to convince a federal judge not to sentence him to any prison time when Ciminelli learns his fate later this month. FAMILIAR FACES in FACEBOOK SCANDAL — Is LYNCH on the ‘NO’ list? — ‘21st-century ANIMAL HOUSE’ — BOSTON POLICE under fire for sharing INTEL

GOOD MORNING, MASSACHUSETTS. TGIF.

FAMILIAR FACES IN FACEBOOK SCANDAL — Facebook axed its relationship with Definers Public Affairs on Thursday after a bombshell New York Times report that the firm spread misinformation on Facebook's behalf in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal. And because there really always is a Massachusetts connection, one of the brains behind the Definers operation worked in the Romney administration on Beacon Hill.

Story Continued Below

Definers Senior Vice President Colin Reed worked for former governor and Utah Senator-elect Mitt Romney in 2006 and 2007 and managed U.S. Ambassador Scott Brown's 2014 Senate campaign in New Hampshire. Most recently, he was executive director of the America Rising PAC during the 2016 election and he touts himself as a vocal critic of Sen. Elizabeth Warren. The founder of Definers also has Romney ties, although they're presidential. Matt Rhoades was the manager of Romney's presidential campaign against President Barack Obama in 2012.

Facebook is under fire for using Definers to share opposition research and spread negative stories about critics, linking them to conservative punching bag George Soros, the Times reports. The practice is pretty common in Washington, but it's a bad look for Facebook, which is already facing sharp criticism for its business practices. Definers defended the research as "entirely factual," according to a POLITICO report .

IS LYNCH ON THE ‘NO’ LIST? — Count Rep. Stephen Lynch as a maybe. The South Boston congressman's office isn't saying whether he'll support Nancy Pelosi for Speaker. As lawmakers work behind the scenes to either secure Pelosi's top spot or topple her, it appears Lynch's name might be on a letter opposing Pelosi, according to a Huffington Post report published Thursday.

Lynch isn't what you'd call a Pelosi ally. In 2015, Lynch said Pelosi should consider resigning as minority leader because she wouldn't lead the party to a majority in 2016. He turned out to be right, and the following year, Lynch, Rep. Seth Moulton and Rep. Mike Capuano voted against her bid for minority leader. And years before, Pelosi had an uncomfortable exchange with Lynch in 2010, when she was rallying support for the health care bill. According to a Boston Globe report at the time, Lynch told Pelosi: “Look, lady, I know a lot about this bill, and I am not for it.’’

title: 'The world’s leading space company that’s been to the moon.'
description: The famed Draper Lab in Cambridge remains a highly sought after partner in the new space race.

fulltext:
"It is absolutely growing. Not just in the United States but around the world." says Jennifer Jensen, a retired Army colonel and acquisition officer who took over earlier this year as Draper's vice president of national security and space. | Courtesy of the Draper Lab POLITICO SPACE 'The world’s leading space company that’s been to the moon.' The famed Draper Lab in Cambridge remains a highly sought after partner in the new space race.

Draper Laboratory's history is intertwined with the American space program, dating back to its work developing the guidance and navigation systems for NASA's Apollo moon missions.

Originally founded in 1932 as the MIT Instrumentation Lab, the non-profit headquartered in Cambridge, Massachusetts, also remains a key partner for the Pentagon and intelligence agencies, including playing a critical role on the Navy's Trident nuclear ballistic missile program.

Story Continued Below

But its engineers are now in steadily higher demand from space agencies and private companies around the world who are developing new satellites and spacecraft and in some cases also angling to go to the moon.

"It is absolutely growing. Not just in the United States but around the world." says Jennifer Jensen, a retired Army colonel and acquisition officer who took over earlier this year as Draper's vice president of national security and space.

"As technology matures different countries have the ability to have their own small space programs, with satellites," she explained, "or put payloads on other satellites that they never did before. So we’re seeing a tremendous growth in that."

POLITICO Space POLITICO’s weekly must-read briefing on the second space age. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Indeed, the lab's work in commercial and civil space "has doubled every year for the last three years," adds Jensen, who came to Draper from Sierra Nevada Corporation.

She spoke about some of the research center's long legacy of technological innovations -- including the atomic clock the first fly-by-wire aircraft, and more recently the solar protection for the avionics on NASA's Parker Probe -- as well as some of its new partnerships with NASA and private firms.

This transcript has been edited for length and clarity.

Tell us about Draper Lab.

We are just about 1,750 people. Of those there is between 1,100 and 1,200 engineers. We are headquartered in Cambridge but we have offices across the country -- in Annapolis; Cape Canaveral; Houston; Huntsville; Pittsfield, Massachusetts; Reston, Virginia; St. Petersburg, Florida; Washington, D.C. Those satellite office s are geared mostly to be close to the customer to make sure we stay attuned with them. Our revenue is close to $600 million year on average.

How is Draper is different from other non-profit research and development centers?

Draper started from the MIT Innovation Lab and it broke out in the 1960s to become an independent nonprofit, which is different from a federally-funded research and development center or university -affiliated research center.

We are just like any other company, basically. We have to compete for every contract that we have. Anything we have from profits we reinvest back into our company to support the national interest and various programs to keep us ahead of technology for our nation.

That is where we differ from the other non-profits. They get funding set aside in a funding line and they get it on an annual basis. They don’t have to go compete. It is just given to them. We have flexibility because we can do any type of contracts. We can do completely commercial contracts. We can do military contracts. We have all sorts of customers and business models. At the same time, our core is we are here as a nonprofit for national interest and security, so we keep that in mind in everything we do.

The moon is in Draper’s DNA.

We were on all the Apollo missions. We did the navigation and guidance. The company basically formed out of that. Everything is stemmed from that in some way or another.

Where is Draper now focused in commercial and civil space sector?

This is a growing business. Our customers there are NASA and then partnerships that we have with commercial industry. For instance, we just announced an award and a partnership with iSpace, a Japanese company that is going back to the moon for lunar mining services. We are partners with them on their navigation and guidance... and the flight computers and subterranean mapping of the moon. That one is completely commercial.

We would potentially use that same type of vehicle for a NASA service, which we also proposed for lunar landing services. It has applicability both ways. That is what is great about Draper. We have these technologies and even though it is developed for one, we can span across and re-purpose it sometimes to other areas. It is pretty exciting that we are going back to the moon in this capacity.

Did you compete for the iSpace project?

They sought us out as a strategic partner. Draper is probably the world’s leading space company that’s been to the moon. We’re the only ones around that has. So these commercial companies frequently seek us out for the navigation and guidance system.

What is the relationship with Sierra Nevada?

We provide the navigation and guidance software in the flight computers for that mission [Dream Chaser]. We just completed a successful demonstration to NASA of that software in the last week in September. That was a major milestone to get through. It went absolutely perfect.

We also announced a teaming relationship we have for lunar landing services for NASA. We brought General Atomics in on that as well, with iSpace. We are doing the power propulsion element for several of the bidders. We have several in the making right now. There is a lot of activity.

We do navigation, landing, autonomy, docking for space stations, terrain mapping. We do micro sat thrusters. We do protection on the Parker Solar Probe. We did the solar protection for the avionics.

How has the space-related work evolved in recent years?

In that particular division division it has doubled every year for the last three years. We should be somewhere between $60 and $70 million this year we're hoping. We hope to exceed it, actually.

It is absolutely growing, Not just in the United States but around the world. As technology matures different countries have the ability to have their own small space programs, with satellites, or put payloads on other satellites that they never did before. So we’re seeing a tremendous growth in that.

How do you view the proposed Space Force?

It is not unlike what happened back in the 30s and 40s when they were assessing whether to have an Air Force or not.

I think they are going through the same thing and trying to make an assessment to see if that is appropriate at this point in time. Our stress is that the funding remain strong for however they decide to do it.

CORRECTION: A previous version misstated the title of the predecessor organization of Draper.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi makes her way to a caucus meeting on Thursday. | M. Scott Mahaskey/POLITICO

DRIVING THE DAY

NEW … ONE WAY FOR NANCY PELOSI TO WIN… There are 48 DAYS until Nancy Pelosi is scheduled to face a floor vote for the speakership, and she is facing resistance like never before. If you talk to Pelosi and her staff, she’ll be the speaker. If you talk to the rebels -- the 20 or so Democrats who want her out -- they say they will take their opposition to the floor and block her from returning to the speakership.

-- BUT HERE IS HOW PELOSI COULD HANG ON: Most everyone says she would win handily if she just simply says when she’d leave. Pelosi has said she wants a “transitional” speakership, but if she gave a date certain -- “I intend to serve until ____” -- she’d win without much hassle, according to supporters and opponents. Of course, that would be close to a last resort. And there certainly are other ways she could win. But several “NeverPelosi’ers” say it would be hard to oppose her if she says she’d leave at a date certain in the next two years.

MEANWHILE … PELOSI ALLIES say she has always seen her leadership role as one term at a time. Further, they say what’s most important is the California Democrat has publicly made clear she’s preparing for generational change and is making explicit commitments to lawmakers about that.

title: Julian Assange could see charges, U.S. court filing suggests
description: Any charges against Assange could help illuminate the question of whether Russia coordinated with the Trump campaign to sway the 2016 presidential election.
content: Julian Assange 47, has resided in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London for more than six years in a bid to avoid being extradited to Sweden, where he was wanted to sex crimes, or to the United States, whose government he has repeatedly humbled with mass disclosur… [+5075 chars]
fulltext:
Julian Assange 47, has resided in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London for more than six years in a bid to avoid being extradited to Sweden, where he was wanted to sex crimes, or to the United States, whose government he has repeatedly humbled with mass disclosures of classified information. | Jack Taylor/Getty Images cybersecurity Julian Assange could see charges, U.S. court filing suggests

WASHINGTON — The Justice Department inadvertently named Julian Assange in a court filing in an unrelated case, suggesting prosecutors have prepared charges against the WikiLeaks founder under seal.

Assange’s name appears twice in an August court filing from a federal prosecutor in Virginia, who was attempting to keep sealed a separate case involving a man accused of coercing a minor for sex.

Story Continued Below

In one sentence, the prosecutor wrote that the charges and arrest warrant “would need to remain sealed until Assange is arrested in connection with the charges in the criminal complaint and can therefore no longer evade or avoid arrest and extradition in this matter.” In another sentence, the prosecutor said that “due to the sophistication of the defendant and the publicity surrounding the case, no other procedure is likely to keep confidential the fact that Assange has been charged.”

Any charges against Assange could help illuminate the question of whether Russia coordinated with the Trump campaign to sway the 2016 presidential election. It would also suggest that, after years of internal wrangling within the Justice Department, prosecutors have decided to take a more aggressive tact against the secret-sharing website.

It was not immediately clear why Assange’s name was included in the document, though Joshua Stueve, a spokesman for the Eastern District of Virginia — which had been investigating Assange — said, “The court filing was made in error. That was not the intended name for this filing.”

The Washington Post reported late Thursday, citing people familiar with the matter, that Assange had indeed been charged. The Associated Press could not immediately confirm that.

It was not immediately clear what charges Assange, who has been holed up for years in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London, might face.
